message.content:
We start by extracting the required figures from the provided statements.

1. Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio  
• Sales (from the income statement – Main Business Revenue) = 22,876,677.56  
• Accounts Receivable at the end is 15,362,611.64 (beginning is 0).  
• Average Accounts Receivable = (0 + 15,362,611.64) / 2 = 7,681,305.82  
• Ratio = 22,876,677.56 / 7,681,305.82 ≈ 2.98  

2. Operating Cash Flow Ratio AND Operating Cash Flow to Current Liabilities Ratio  
The cash flow statement shows:  
• Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –16,772,398.72  
• Total Current Liabilities = 3,143,833.89 (from balance sheet)  
• Ratio = –16,772,398.72 / 3,143,833.89 ≈ –5.34  
(Note: Here both ratios are computed the same way.)  

3. Total Asset Turnover Ratio  
• Sales = 22,876,677.56  
• Total Assets: Beginning = 28,000,000.00 and End = 33,082,821.36  
• Average Total Assets = (28,000,000.00 + 33,082,821.36) / 2 = 30,541,410.68  
• Ratio = 22,876,677.56 / 30,541,410.68 ≈ 0.75  

4. Debt to Equity Ratio  
• Total Liabilities are calculated from the balance sheet as:  
  Total Liabilities = Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity – Total Owner's Equity  
  = 33,082,821.36 – 29,938,987.47 = 3,143,833.89  
• Total Owner’s Equity (end) = 29,938,987.47  
• Ratio = 3,143,833.89 / 29,938,987.47 ≈ 0.105, which rounds to 0.11  

Thus, the final answers are:

{
  "solution": {
    "Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio": "2.98",
    "operating cash flow ratio": "-5.34",
    "operating cash flow to current liabilities ratio": "-5.34",
    "Total Asset Turnover Ratio": "0.75",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.11"
  }
}
